summary: The Normal distribution is probably the most useful of all. Most physical characteristics naturally exhibit a normal distribution, and many other distributions at scale tend towards it (courtesy of the Central Limit Theorem). | A defining feature of the normal distribution is that the mean, mode and median are equal, resulting in its iconic ‘Bell shaped’ symmetrical probability distribution curve.

The Poisson distribution is very handy for modeling the number of times something happens in a given interval of time. | Say for example a shop gets on average 10 customers every hour, the Poisson distribution could help study and predict the customers’ visiting patterns.

The Bernoulli distribution models situations which would go one of two possible ways: success or failure, with probabilities p and q=1-p respectively. For example, a coin toss. | If the two events are equally likely, p=0.5.

For uniform distributions, all values have equal probability. A good example is rolling a (fair) die; all six faces have the same odds of topping (probability = 1/6). | All the values in a uniformly distributed interval (a,b) have probability 1/(b-a).

The Geometric distribution helps model the number of tries it will take before registering the first success. For example, the number of failures before an experiment succeeds or an athlete hits a target.
The Alpha distribution is widely applied in models and tests for reliability and lifetime.
The Beta distribution has many applications in Bayesian inference, which attempts to determine the likelihood of events based on some prior condition or knowledge.

The chi-square distribution is derived from the summation of standardized & squared normally distributed variables. It is essential in tests for hypotheses as most test statistics are approximately chi-square distributed.

The Exponential distribution models the time intervals between events occurring at a constant rate (having a Poisson distribution). | It can help analyse the inter-arrival times of customers i.e how long a stall will stay idle before the next customer comes assuming 40 customers come in every hour.
The F distribution is crucial in tests of hypothesis using the Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) methods.
parameter_info: ν >0(degrees of freedom), ω > 0 (degrees of freedom)

summary: The Gamma family of distributions has many research applications, most notably in predicting rainfall and designing models that exhibit certain characteristics to allow prototyping.

The Pareto distribution models features where a large proportion of observations come from a small amount of variables e.g. most notably the imbalances in income distribution. Also, human settlement patterns and error rates.
The Student’s t-test is very useful for estimating the mean of small, normally distributed samples, and for testing the significance of the difference in two sample means.

The Binomial distribution models the number of success for n Bernoulli trials (succeed or fail scenarios). A common application is determining whether a desired threshold will be met given a predetermined fail rate.
parameter_info: n > 0 (no. of trials), 0<=p<=1 (defaults to 0.5 for p>1)

summary: The Negative Binomial distribution models the number of successes before the ith failure. A possible application is in predicting the number of wins before the third failure, given the likelihood of success on each attempt.
parameter_info: n > 0 (no. of trials), 0<=p<=1 (defaults to 0.5 for p>1)
